abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Pilot Fishery
            Development Project for Albania were as follows: outcomes
            were satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            moderate, the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the
            Borrower performance was also satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: although assessed as a high risk operation
            at the time of appraisal, due to the conditions prevailing
            at that time it was also viewed as the appropriate approach
            to re-establishing control of the fisheries sector and
            taking first steps toward its sustainable development.
            Project objectives have been largely achieved, and the risky
            strategy has proven to be appropriate. Frequent and
            substantive guidance and support made available by the
            supervision team was instrumental in capturing the benefits
            of this approach. The availability and distribution of
            Government subsidized fuel to fishing vessel owners via the
            Fisheries Management Organizations (FMOs) provided an
            economic incentive for vessel owners to become members, and
            also helped FMOs establish financial self sufficiency. While
            Government and sector stakeholders have achieved significant
            progress in establishing the institutional framework for
            co-management, sustainability of FMOs, their effective
            operation of port facilities, and implementation of fishery
            co-management will require continued leadership and
            strategically targeted support from Government beyond the
            five year life of the project. This should include provision
            of joint training for FMO and fisheries inspectorate staff,
            and collaborative development of operational procedures.
